title: Chemistry Urgently Needs to Develop Safer Materials - Scientific American
summary: The article discusses a train derailment that caused an environmental disaster due to toxic chemicals, highlighting the need for safer chemical transport and a rethinking of the chemistry used in our economy. It calls for the creation of safer and more sustainable chemicals, processes, materials, and products to prevent such incidents and promote environmental and human health. It emphasizes the need to transition to safer chemicals and products, highlighting the challenges and opportunities in advancing sustainable chemistry and addressing hazards in the current chemical industry.
green_innovation: TRUE The article discusses the need for safer and more sustainable chemicals, processes, materials, and products, which aligns with green innovation principles aiming to reduce negative environmental impacts of human activities.
business_innovation: FALSE The focus of the article is on the need for safer and more sustainable chemicals and products related to environmental and human health, rather than a new product or business process in the traditional business innovation sense.
green_product: TRUE The article emphasizes the importance of transitioning to greener, safer chemicals and products while highlighting the hazards of current chemical use, showing a commitment to reducing environmental impacts throughout the product life cycle.
green_process: TRUE The article advocates for the development of greener and more sustainable chemical processes to address hazards in the current chemical industry, aiming to promote environmental sustainability and reduce negative environmental impacts.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 482111 - Line-Haul Railroads; 325110 - Petrochemical Manufacturing; 325320 - Pesticide and Other Agricultural Chemical Manufacturing; 325510 - Paint and Coating Manufacturing
greenwashing: FALSE The article does not exhibit greenwashing as it raises genuine concerns about the environmental and health hazards associated with current chemical products and processes, emphasizing the need for safer and more sustainable alternatives.

title: Literacy rate impact on innovations and environmental pollution in China - Frontiers
summary: The article examines the impact of literacy rate and innovations on environmental pollution in China from 1990 to 2021, finding a positive effect of literacy on short- and long-term innovations. The study suggests the importance of education in boosting innovation and highlights the need for environmental protection laws to address pollution alongside literacy enhancement.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 611710 - Educational Support Services, 541710 - Research and Development in the Physical, Engineering, and Life Sciences, 611430 - Professional and Management Development Training, 926130 - Environmental Protection Organizations
